column4: hi, apparently my windows key is not recognised as Super key but as Mod4 although I bound Super to it in gnome keyboard settings - how do I fix this?
you can use xmodmap to change it.  There may be an easier way, though.

xmodmap is a lower level X utility, so it will work with gnome, but using it is more than a bit arcane.
so is "Super" something you can bind? :)
or any idea how to reset keyboard settings completely?
you can bind anything at that level, but as I said, the syntax is odd.
one thing you can do is, if the mapping is correct at boot, you can use xmodmap to generate a configuration file.  You can then restore that configuration at anytime with xmodmap
to see what you are dealing with, run the "xev" utility, put the mouse in xev's window, and press various keys.  You'll see how it works
but it's very low level; you'll see meta up, meta down, that sort of thing
if you can figure out the syntax, you can quite literally make any key do anything.  I've used it to move the shift lock key location, for example.
